title: so did riot just kill iceborn gauntlet for anyone with a built in slow?
body: see title, does the change to slows mean trundle is screwed out of iceborn?

replies.body:
Removing stacking slows will make Iceborn Gauntlet, Rylai's, Red buff etc less valuable on champions that already have slows on their kits. It also somewhat reduces the value of having multiple champions with frequent slows on the same team. We believe it's a good change for the game though in large part because slows most affect champions without dashes/blinks/leaps. We'd like to help those immobile champs out a bit, reduce some of the power discrepancy between dash/no dash.

As far as champs like Trundle go we still expect Iceborn Gauntlet to be a decent option. His Q slow has a really short duration, so the overlap period is brief, while his E slow's got a pretty limited radius. It's not as valuable a pick up as it was, but should still be viable. Additionally, as a melee champ very dependent on his own movement speed, we also expect Trundle to be one of the more noticeable beneficiaries of this change, in terms of what he has to deal with from the enemy team.

> [{quoted}](name=sixdogman,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Xtuj4g0j,comment-id=000900030000000400000000,timestamp=2015-07-08T19:32:19.705+0000)
>

The patch notes comment is only talking about how abilities are categorized for which slow amount they get from {{item:3116}} .

You're mixing the two.

In the case of Rylais - if a spell fits into multiple categories for the items slow, it will use the weakest one.

In the case of multiple slows from different sources on the same target, the most powerful slow currently on the target will apply. For example, if someone walks over a teem mushroom while withered by Nasus, the mushrooms slow will be negated by the wither. However, if the wither expires while the mushroom slow would still be active, it applies for the remainder of its duration

K i found a example of old slow stacking system

Example
A champion with a raw movement speed of 400 is affected by a 2 second long 40% slow and a 5 second long 20% slow at the same time.

For the first two seconds, they will have (1 − 0.4) × (1 − 0.2 × 0.35) = 0.6 × 0.93 = 55.8% of his original movement speed (a 44.2% effective slow). So he will have 400 × 0.558 = 223.2 raw movement speed.
For the following three seconds, the effective slow will be 20% and so he will have 400 × 0.8 = 320 movement speed.

How does the new slow stacking work if you apply a 40% 1 second slow and a 20% 5 second slow?

Does it slow you for 40% for 1 second and 20 % for 4 seconds?

Meedler's answer  for** new slow stacking system**

40% for 1 second, then 20% for the next 4 seconds. Both of the debuffs still end up on the target, they're just only affected by the strongest slow currently present. (U lose 1 second duration)

**Old slow stacking **

Slow stacking
Slowing effects follow particular rules when stacking:

If a champion is affected by multiple slows, the strongest one will be fully applied, while the others are applied sequentially with 65% reduced effectiveness down to 35% (effectiveness not duration)  of its original strength.
